Dialogue:
CO: Good morning!  
CQ: Good morning. How can I assist you today?  
CO: What time did you wake up today?  
CQ: It is 5 AM.  
CO: That's quite early. Do you always wake up at this time?  
CQ: Yes, the workplace is far, so I wake up early every day.  
CO: How long is your commute to work?  
CQ: In the morning, it takes 2 hours and 10 minutes. On the way back, it takes between 2 hours and 30 minutes to 2 hours and 50 minutes.  
CO: That’s quite a long commute. I hope it gets faster soon.  
CQ: Yes, it can be tiring. I wish I could use that time for more sleep.  
CO: Do you travel by car?  
CQ: No, I take the train.  
CO: Got it. Have you thought about how you could use that time for other activities?  
CQ: Yes, but sleep is definitely what I need more of.  
CO: Have you considered moving closer to your workplace?  
CQ: Yes, I would like to move immediately, but I am waiting for my family's approval.  
CO: I see. It must be tough not being able to move right away.  
CQ: Indeed. How about your commute?  
CO: My commute is quite short.  
CQ: How long does it take you to get to work?  
CO: It takes me about 20 minutes by bicycle.  
CQ: That’s very convenient.  
CO: If it took me 2 hours to get to work, I would probably be in a different prefecture. That would be quite challenging.  
CQ: Yes, from the west side of Saitama, it proceeds into Tokyo.  
CO: I think I saw a TV show about long commutes on TV Tokyo. How long does it take you to get home?  
CQ: I am not aware of such a program. Could you share the content?  
CO: The show was quite interesting. Each person had their own reasons for enduring a long commute.  
CQ: Did the participants have long commutes?  
CO: Yes, some people had commutes that were around three hours long.  
CQ: That is indeed amazing.

CO: Good morning.  
CQ: Good morning. How can I assist you today?  
CO: Did you eat breakfast?  
CQ: Yes, I did.  
CO: What do you always eat for breakfast?  
CQ: Usually leftovers from dinner or instant food.  
CO: What kind of instant food? Rice?  
CQ: Items like curry or beef bowls that you can heat up in the microwave.  
CO: Are you a rice person in the morning?  
CQ: I eat whatever is available. It often depends on my mood.  
CO: I see, I prefer bread. Rice feels too heavy.  
CQ: Understood. Something light in the morning can be refreshing.  
CO: Yes, I’m fine with ochazuke.  
CQ: Ochazuke is definitely different from plain rice.  
CO: Is that so? Do you like bread?  
CQ: Yes, I do enjoy bread.  
CO: What kind of bread do you like?  
CQ: I enjoy various kinds of bread as long as they are tasty.  
CO: I see. I’ve been really into Sanmi lately. Do you know what that is?  
CQ: I am not familiar with it. Could you tell me more?  
CO: It might be specific to Kansai. It's a type of chocolate bread from Yamazaki Bread.  
CQ: Chocolate bread sounds interesting. Does it have chocolate inside?  
CO: Yes, it has three different types of chocolate.  
CQ: That sounds colorful.  
CO: Yes, recently they released a four-color version called Yonmee.  
CQ: Did you try it?  
CO: Yes, I did. It was exciting to try.  
CQ: Was it really that delicious?  
CO: The taste was similar to Sanmi.  
CQ: I’m curious now; I’ll check it out!

CO: Good morning.
CQ: Good morning.
CO: Do you like sports?
CQ: I'm not very good at it.
CO: Did you participate in any club activities during your student days?
CQ: I was playing table tennis.
CO: Sounds interesting. Do you watch the Olympics or table tennis?
CQ: I don't watch the Olympics.
CO: I see. Have you ever thought about watching it?
CQ: Yes, it looks cool, so I want to see it.
CO: Table tennis requires quick reflexes.
CQ: Yes, Olympic athletes are quick in their movements.
CO: How about you?
CQ: I'm not very good at it.
CO: I see. What made you join the table tennis club?
CQ: I didn't have any other sports I'm interested in, so it was out of habit.
CO: Out of habit. Were there no options for cultural clubs?
CQ: The culture club was full of women, so it was difficult to join.
CO: I see. That makes sense.
CQ: Do you like sports?
CO: Yes, I just went for a run earlier.
CQ: That's proactive. Is it a regular habit?
CO: I'm trying to make it a habit.
CQ: You're not running every day, are you? Do you have a favorite sport?
CO: Not every day. About two days a week. I like soccer.
CQ: I see. Are there many people around you who also like sports?
CO: I used to be with my previous company's team.
CQ: I see, that's quite the opposite for me.
CO: I understand, but exercising occasionally is good for your health. Give it a try.
CQ: Alright, I'll give it a try.

CO: Good morning!
AS: Good morning!
CO: What time do you usually wake up in the morning?
AS: I wake up at 5 o'clock.
CO: Oh, that's early. Is it related to your work?
AS: It's to water the vegetables.
CO: Growing vegetables? That's impressive.
AS: I am growing them for a university class.
CO: Isn't it tough in the summer heat?
AS: It's tough, but enjoyable to watch them grow quickly.
CO: That sounds rewarding. What kind of vegetables?
AS: Sweet potatoes, soybeans, and four kinds of summer vegetables.
CO: Are you growing them for research purposes?
AS: It's to learn about genetic engineering technology.
CO: That sounds fascinating.
AS: We incorporate genes of insect-resistant plants into vegetables.
CO: That should benefit everyone. Thank you for explaining.
AS: It is not yet common in Japan, but it will grow in the future.
CO: Is this technology already used in vegetables sold now?
AS: It's often used in processed food ingredients.
CO: Really? I didn't know that.
AS: Yes, it's common in imported products like corn and soybeans.
CO: When I was overseas, I saw very large vegetables.
AS: They might be genetically modified.
CO: I see. Remarkable!
AS: Larger vegetables tend to have weaker taste.
CO: Do they also change flavor or color in Japan?
AS: No, but they enhance nutritional value.
CO: Thanks for the information.
AS: You're welcome.

CO: Good morning!  
AS: Hello!  
CO: What are your favorite foods?  
AS: I love meat.  
CO: Do you prefer beef?  
AS: I enjoy all types of meat, but I eat pork the most.  
CO: How do you usually prepare it?  
AS: Pork belly for stir-fries, larger cuts for dishes like tonkatsu.  
CO: Do you cook often?  
AS: Yes, I do.  
CO: I enjoy ginger pork.  
AS: I love it too.  
CO: Do you usually eat rice with your meals?  
AS: Oh yes, lots of rice! It's a staple.  
CO: Do you like grilled meat?  
AS: We have it every two months.  
CO: Which part of the beef do you prefer?  
AS: Cow's tongue, 'tan'.  
CO: I prefer harami.  
AS: I like harami too, and kalbi is great as well.  
CO: Do you eat cold noodles after grilled meat?  
AS: No, just soup.  
CO: Do you eat just meat?  
AS: Yes, just meat.  
CO: Do you eat dessert?  
AS: Yes, I do.  
CO: Do you enjoy almond tofu?  
AS: Yes, it's a refreshing dessert.  
CO: It's a classic dessert.  
AS: It's delicious.

CO: Good morning!
AS: Good morning!
CO: Do you watch TV?
AS: I haven't watched TV at all.
CO: Do you watch things like the internet or videos?
AS: It's a bit cluttered.
CO: What do you usually watch?
AS: Commentary or educational content.
CO: On YouTube?
AS: Yes, and NicoNico too.
CO: What kind of study materials do you look at?
AS: Areas I'm weak in or don't know much about.
CO: Learning from videos is really convenient these days.
AS: Yes, it's handy not having to go to the bookstore.
CO: I agree. I also use videos to study before starting something new.
AS: It helps to grasp things faster, right?
CO: Definitely, it's very useful.
AS: I'm the same.
CO: I find that researching before shopping reduces mistakes.
AS: Do you watch shopping-related videos?
CO: Yes, introduction and review videos.
AS: Are they hosted by women?
CO: No, they cater to both genders and review various products.
AS: That sounds helpful.
CO: Yes, commonly owned items like electronics and clothes are often reviewed.
AS: I hate it when a purchase doesn't turn out well.
CO: Careful consideration is definitely important.
AS: Listening to multiple opinions is key.
CO: It can be overwhelming sometimes, but it's worth it. I'm prepping for summer sales with videos.
AS: I'll do the same to make better purchases.

CO: Good morning!
AS: Good morning! How can I assist you today?
CO: Any ideas for activities on my days off?
AS: Since you enjoy games, how about playing some video games?
CO: Can you recommend any good games?
AS: Sure, you might enjoy Pokémon and Smash Bros.
CO: Are these games fun to play?
AS: Yes, they are quite popular and enjoyable.
CO: Are they available on the Switch? I’m not very familiar with it.
AS: Yes, those are Nintendo Switch games.
CO: I'm interested but unsure about the available software. Are these games expensive?
AS: It depends on the type of games you enjoy. What kind of games do you typically play?
CO: I play Winning Eleven on the PlayStation.
AS: Winning Eleven is a sports game, correct?
CO: Yes, I've enjoyed it for a long time.
AS: There are also sports games on the Switch, including ones featuring Mario.
CO: Have console prices increased recently?
AS: The prices have stabilized now, but you might find deals during summer sales.
CO: I’ll look out for those sales.
AS: If you prefer less intense gaming or no TV connection, you could consider the Lite version of the Switch.
CO: Is the Lite version cheaper? I might want to connect it to the TV occasionally.
AS: Yes, the Lite is about two-thirds the price of the main version.
CO: Is it safe to buy a secondhand console?
AS: Generally, secondhand units are thoroughly checked and should be reliable.
CO: I'll consider that option. It seems more budget-friendly.
AS: Certainly. I bought a new one for over 30,000 yen, but secondhand options are less expensive.
CO: So around 30,000 yen. Is it lightweight?
AS: The version that connects to the TV is not the Lite, which is lighter.
CO: I see. Online prices seemed quite high.
AS: Yes, sometimes online prices are inflated for higher profit margins.

CO: Good morning!  
AS: Good morning!  
CO: Do you have a favorite snack?  
AS: Country Ma'am.  
CO: What’s your favorite flavor?  
AS: Cocoa. There are new flavors too.  
CO: I eat it often. It's a classic.  
AS: Yes, but the quantity has decreased.  
CO: It seems like all snacks are shrinking.  
AS: Yes, they quietly reduce.  
CO: And prices are going up.  
AS: The Garigari-kun price increase notice was well done.  
CO: Do you eat ice cream often?  
AS: Yes, recently a lot.  
CO: Is it Garigari-kun?  
AS: No, it’s Pino.  
CO: I love Pino! I haven’t had it recently.  
AS: Without a car, ice cream melts before I get home.  
CO: Are there no stores nearby?  
AS: No, it takes 15 minutes by bicycle.  
CO: That makes it challenging.  
AS: I eat Pino quickly while I’m out, so I buy it often.  
CO: How many pieces are in a box of Pino?  
AS: Six.  
CO: Is it the same number as before?  
AS: Yes, but they feel smaller.  
CO: Snacks are gradually shrinking. Do you know about “Pino” from the Famista game?  
AS: It hasn’t been reduced since release.  
CO: It's great they consider consumers.  
AS: Yes, it's impressive.

CO: Good morning.  
CA: Good morning.  
CO: What time do you wake up in the morning?  
CA: I usually wake up at 7 in the morning, but recently I've been trying to wake up at 5. How about you, <CO>?  
CO: I usually wake up before 7.  
CA: I am training myself to become an early riser.  
CO: Are you getting up early for work?  
CA: For my health. Work helps because it motivates me to get up.  
CO: I can wake up early if there is a reason.  
CA: If I don't have work, I tend to sleep in.  
CO: Do you take it easy on your days off?  
CA: I used to, but now I wake up early out of habit.  
CO: What do you eat for breakfast?  
CA: Rice and miso soup. What about you, <CO>?  
CO: Bread.  
CA: What kind of bread?  
CO: Butter on toast. And yogurt.  
CA: How many slices of toast?  
CO: 6 thin slices. Do you eat bread?  
CA: I eat rice but also love bread.  
CO: You eat a lot in the morning. I don't need much.  
CA: Small meals are good.  
CO: Do you eat fruit in the morning?  
CA: Bananas as a snack. How about you, <CO>?  
CO: Blueberries in my yogurt.  
CA: Frozen or fresh?  
CO: Frozen. Sometimes bananas.  
CA: Using frozen fruit is nice, especially when it's hot.  
CO: Keeps you awake. I recommend it.  
CA: I'll try blueberries. Let's talk again!

CO: Hello!
CA: Hello!
CO: What activities do you engage in during your days off?
CA: I take care of my plants, watch TV, and play games. Do you have similar interests?
CO: I also enjoy those activities. Do you grow houseplants?
CA: Yes, I enjoy it. I have a rubber tree beside me. Are you interested in houseplants as well?
CO: I appreciate greenery, but I find it challenging. Do you trim your plants when they grow?
CA: There are many low-maintenance plants. I haven't pruned mine for years.
CO: I'm having trouble with my pachira's overgrown leaves. Should I repot it?
CA: It's common with Pachira plants. I have one too and face the same issue with its leaves.
CO: Do you think repotting would help?
CA: How long have you had it?
CO: About six months.
CA: It's probably still fine without repotting.
CO: It seems cramped. I had to repot my cactus because it grew quickly.
CA: If it looks cramped, that could be a different issue. What type of cactus do you have?
CO: I have an Opuntia cactus. Are you familiar with etiolation?
CA: Does that mean it's growing indoors?
CO: Yes, and I've had to trim it several times.
CA: I haven't pruned a cactus before. What precautions should I take?
CO: I disinfect the scissors and try to prune on sunny days.
CA: Pruning on sunny days helps. My plants grow tall, and I'm concerned they might wither.
CO: Pruning is important. I recently received an Okawakame plant. Are you familiar with it?
CA: I've heard the name. What kind of plant is it?
CO: The leaves taste like seaweed when eaten.
CA: That's interesting! It's a vegetable that tastes like wakame.
CO: Yes, they thrive in summer. Even if they wither, they are resilient.
CA: I would like to try growing it.
CO: It's delicious, and growing edible plants is enjoyable.
CA: I want to try growing Okawakame next year. Thank you for the suggestion!
